item.title: A tribe in Maine is using opioid settlement funds on a sweat lodge to treat addiction
item.description: Hundreds of Native American tribes are getting money from lawsuit settlements with opioid companies. Some are investing the new funds in traditional healing practices to treat addiction.

item.title: Kenya's Samburu boys share a sacred bond. Why one teen broke with the brotherhood
item.description: After initiation rites – including circumcision – the boys leave their families to take charge of the herds, driving them high into the mountains. It's a way of life that climate change is testing.

item.title: A car-free town in the Amazon serves lessons for pedaling to net zero emissions
item.description: Afuá, a remote town in the Brazilian Amazon, banned motor vehicles over 20 years ago. Writer Mac Margolis and photographer Stefan Kolumban paid the town a visit to see what life is like.
item.content:encoded:
Since 2002, this city on the banks of the Amazon River has been famously off limits to motor vehicles.'/>

item.title: Controlled demolition planned at Baltimore bridge collapse site
item.description: After weeks of preparation, crews are scheduled to conduct a controlled demolition Sunday to break down the largest remaining span of the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge in Maryland.

item.title: Switzerland's Nemo wins Eurovision 2024 in a year of protests
item.description: The Swiss singer and rapper was one of two nonbinary artists in the finals at this year's event held in Malmo, Sweden. Meanwhile, protesters called for Israel's disqualification from the contest.

item.title: A federal judge temporarily halts U.S. plan to lower credit card late fees to $8
item.description: The temporary injunction imposed by Judge Mark Pittman in the Northern District of Texas is a win for the big banks and major credit card companies. The plan was set to go into effect next week.

item.description: The Supreme Court justice told attendees at a judicial conference that he and his wife have faced "nastiness" and "lies" over the last several years and decried Washington as a "hideous place."

item.title: Flash floods have killed more than 300 people in Afghanistan
item.description: Floods from heavy seasonal rains have destroyed over 1,000 houses, the U.N. food agency said. A U.N. official said the floods are a reminder of Afghanistan's vulnerability to the climate crisis.

item.title: Israel expands evacuation orders in Rafah as aid groups struggle to prepare
item.description: Israel's military issued new evacuation orders in Gaza's southernmost city of Rafah, forcing even more Palestinians to relocate on Saturday ahead of a likely expanded ground operation there.

item.title: 'Women and Children First' is a tale about how actions and choices affect others
item.description: The puzzle of a girl's death propels Alina Grabowski's debut novel but, really, it's less about the mystery and more about how our actions impact each other, especially when we think we lack agency.
